import React, { useState } from 'react'; import styles from './style.module.css'; const BasicCss: React.FC = () => { const [isToggled, setIsToggled] = useState(false); return (

Basic CSS for Beginners

Learn Traditional, Global, Responsive, PostCSS & Module CSS

Learn Traditional, Global, Responsive, PostCSS & Module CSS

{/* Traditional CSS Example */}

1. Traditional CSS

This box uses traditional CSS properties like:

  • Background color
  • Padding & Margin
  • Border & Border-radius
  • Font properties
{/* Global CSS Example */}

2. Global CSS

This uses global CSS class defined in global styles.

Global styles affect the entire application.

{/* Responsive CSS Example */}

3. Responsive CSS

Item 1
Item 2
Item 3
Item 4

This grid adapts to different screen sizes using media queries.

{/* PostCSS Features Example */}

4. PostCSS Features

This demonstrates PostCSS features like:

  • CSS Variables (Custom Properties)
  • Autoprefixer (vendor prefixes)
  • Nested selectors
  • Color functions
{/* CSS Modules Example */}

5. CSS Modules

CSS Modules provide:

  • Scoped styles (no global conflicts)
  • Dynamic class names
  • Composition
{/* Interactive Examples */}

6. Interactive Examples

Hover Effects

Hover over this card to see the effect!

CSS Animations

This box has a continuous animation

CSS Transitions

Smooth transitions on state changes

{/* Best Practices */}

7. CSS Best Practices

✅ Use Semantic Class Names

Choose descriptive names that describe the purpose, not appearance.

Keep Specificity Low

Avoid deeply nested selectors and !important when possible.

Mobile-First Approach

Start with mobile styles, then enhance for larger screens.

Use CSS Variables

Define colors, spacing, and other values as CSS custom properties.

© 2024 Basic CSS Tutorial - Built with React & CSS Modules

); }; export default BasicCss;
